supporting_quotes: She studied medicine at and graduated with a Doctor of Medicine degree from Dow Medical College in Karachi, Pakistan.
After graduating, she went to the USA to complete an internship in gynaecology and obstetrics at City Hospital in Baltimore, Maryland
finished her further education at the Johns Hopkins University.
She returned to Pakistan in 1954 with her husband, to become a civilian doctor in army hospitals. She worked until 1963 in women's and children's wards in Pakistan Armed Forces hospitals.
In 1964, Sadik was appointed head of the Health Section of the Government's Planning Commission.
Sadik joined the Pakistan Central Family Planning Council in 1966 as Director of Planning and Training
She was appointed Deputy Director-General in 1968
and Director-General in 1970.
Sadik joined the UN Population Fund in 1971.
UN Secretary-General Javier Pérez de Cuéllar appointed her to succeed him, in 1987, thus becoming the first woman to head one of the United Nations' major voluntarily-funded programmes.
former executive director of the United Nations Population Fund (UNFPA) from 1987 to 2000. She retired from the post in December 2000.

organizations: International Conference on Population and Development
supporting_quotes: In June 1990, the Secretary-General of the United Nations appointed Sadik Secretary-General of the International Conference on Population and Development (ICPD), 1994.

roles: Special Adviser to the UN Secretary General
Special Envoy for HIV/AIDS in Asia
supporting_quotes: was a Pakistani physician, Special Adviser to the UN Secretary General with additional responsibilities as Special Envoy for HIV/AIDS in Asia

roles: member of the Board of Governors
supporting_quotes: She was a member of the Board of Governors of the Foundation for Human Development

organizations: South Asian Commission on the Asian Challenge
supporting_quotes: a member of the South Asian Commission on the Asian Challenge
Sadik was the President of the Society for International Development (SID) for the period 1994–1997.

organizations: Association of Physicians of Pakistani Descent of North America
supporting_quotes: Nafis Sadik also was a member of Association of Physicians of Pakistani Descent of North America.

After her retirement from the United Nations Population Fund, she served on several boards of directors and advisory panels of non-profit organizations and research institutions in the area of population control including on the Advisor Board for the German Foundation for World Population.
Sadik was an Emeritus Member of Population Action International.
(1995) Prince Mahidol Award from the Prince Mahidol Award Foundation (Branch Public Health)
(2000) Margaret Sanger Award from the Planned Parenthood Federation of America
(2001) United Nations Population Award
Nafis Sadik (2001)

organizations: World Association of Girl Guides and Girl Scouts
supporting_quotes: (2002) World Citizenship Award from the World Association of Girl Guides and Girl Scouts

supporting_quotes: Award from The Royal College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists
